subs.text: All that is why you want to tie them all together to so you can use multiple tools to work on them, like PDF or GIF or RSS. The format is way too valuable to lock the user into a single editor.

@judell @nathanwallace @steampipeio A question, why not use the names of elements as RSS defines them? Why use different names?

Example, instead of 

select published, title, author_name, feed_link from ...

do this

select pubDate, title, author, link from

the latter are the actual names of values for RSS items

subs.rawText:
Taylor's philosophy is the same as mine. 

When I started blogging back in 1994, mostly to the tech industry via the web and email, everyone thought I was launching an expensive newsletter. I kept saying no, I'm doing this because I want to get these ideas out there. That's all. https://t.co/BSZcOKMaoe

subs.text: But I was flattered that they thought my writing was good enough for that. Soon after I started blogging I got an offer to write for Wired, which I jumped at. They paid me $500 per column. Still, I wasn't doing it for money. I just wanted to show people what was coming in tech.
subs.rawText: But I was flattered that they thought my writing was good enough for that. Soon after I started blogging I got an offer to write for Wired, which I jumped at. They paid me $500 per column. Still, I wasn't doing it for money. I just wanted to show people what was coming in tech.

subs.text: Now, I *love* to make money. But the money wasn't in the subscription fees, it was in inventing something new and huge and then monetizing that in some way, and as it turned out, when I had a choice betw doing something huge or monetizing, I always went for #1.

subs.text:
@rroudt @thunknotes An example. In the early 90s, my company had a programmable outliner called Frontier. It had a rich scripting language and object database. Easy to develop in. People liked the outliner. 

cont'd
subs.rawText:
@rroudt @thunknotes An example. In the early 90s, my company had a programmable outliner called Frontier. It had a rich scripting language and object database. Easy to develop in. People liked the outliner. 

cont'd

subs.text: @rroudt @thunknotes At the time there were two leading page layout and prepress products, Pagemaker and Quark XPress. It turns out there was a strong connection between page layout, scripting and outlining. There was lots you could in the intersection.
subs.rawText: @rroudt @thunknotes At the time there were two leading page layout and prepress products, Pagemaker and Quark XPress. It turns out there was a strong connection between page layout, scripting and outlining. There was lots you could in the intersection.

subs.text: @rroudt @thunknotes Instead of PageMaker and Quark doing their own outliner, scripting system, object databases, that were incompatible, instead they created APIs and we wrote glue for them in Frontier, so people had their choice. And other people made outliners and scripting systems.
subs.rawText: @rroudt @thunknotes Instead of PageMaker and Quark doing their own outliner, scripting system, object databases, that were incompatible, instead they created APIs and we wrote glue for them in Frontier, so people had their choice. And other people made outliners and scripting systems.

subs.text: @rroudt @thunknotes Since these products were often used inside organizations, this meant companies could build their own workflows to take more of the work out of the layout process, and writers could use whatever tools they liked.
subs.rawText: @rroudt @thunknotes Since these products were often used inside organizations, this meant companies could build their own workflows to take more of the work out of the layout process, and writers could use whatever tools they liked.
